name: 1,1'-carbonyldiimidazole
Reason: 1,1'-Carbonyldiimidazole has a melting point that we can compare to 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene, which has a melting point of -109.4 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 1,1'-carbonyldiimidazole, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the carbonyl group introduces a dipole moment, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point by approximately +10°C.
